facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 250 of 1964 was filed in the Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 250 of 1964. Appeal from the judgment and order dated

facts.text: Appeal from judgment and order dated November 1959 of Madras High Court in Writ Appeal No. 46 of 1959.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the judgment and order dated November 1959, of the Madras High Court in Writ Appeal No. 46 of 1959. Ram Reddy and A. V. V. Nair, for the appellants.

facts.text: Appellant Mohd. Ayub Khan petitioned High Court of Madras for writ of mandamus.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant Mohd. Ayub Khan petitioned the, High Court of Madras for a writ of mandamus restraining the Commissioner of Police, Madras, from taking action pu

facts.text: Commissioner of Police, Madras, ordered to refrain from action pursuant to Government of Madras Home Department order No. 83546 dated May 28, 1958.

anchor.surface_text: restraining the Commissioner of Police, Madras, from taking action pursuant to the order of the Government of Madras, Home Department, No. 83546, dated May 28, 1958 and from interfering with the appellants rights as a citizen of India.

facts.text: Petition dismissed by Balakrishna Ayyar, J.

anchor.surface_text: The petition was dismissed by Balakrishna Ayyar, J., and the order was companyfirmed in appeal by a Division Bench of the High Court.

facts.text: Order confirmed in appeal by Division Bench of High Court.

anchor.surface_text: and the order was companyfirmed in appeal by a Division Bench of the High Court. With certificate granted by the High Court, the appellant has appealed to this Court.

facts.text: Appellant claims status of Indian citizen on commencement of Constitution as ordinarily resident for not less than five years preceding that date.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant, who claims that he had acquired the status of an Indian citizen on the companymencement of, the Constitution as a person who had been ordinarily resident in the territory of India for number less than five years immediately preceding that date,

facts.text: Appellant served notice dated July 17, 1957 informing he obtained Pakistan Passport No. 071377 dated April 1, 1953 and must leave India within one month.

anchor.surface_text: was served with a numberice dated July 17, 1957 informing him that as he had obtained Pakistan Passport No. 071377, dated April 1, 1953 he should leave India within one month from the date of service of the numberice,

facts.text: On August 19, 1957, appellant applied to Collector of Madras for registration as citizen of India.

anchor.surface_text: On August 19, 1957, the appellant applied to the Collector of Madras for registration as a citizen of India. Later he applied to the Central Government under S. 9  2  of the Citizenship Act, 1955

facts.text: Appellant applied to Central Government under S. 9(2) of Citizenship Act, 1955 to determine if he continued as citizen and for opportunity to produce evidence.

anchor.surface_text: Later he applied to the Central Government under S. 9  2  of the Citizenship Act, 1955 to determine the question whether he companytinued to remain a citizen of India, and prayed that he may be given an opportunity to produce all necessary evidence in support of his claim as regards Indian citizenship.

facts.text: Government of India by order dated May 7, 1958 rejected appellant's application under s.9 without affording opportunity.

anchor.surface_text: Without affording him that opportunity, however, the Government of India by order, dated May 7, 1958 rejected the application of the appellant under s. 9 of the Citizenship Act.

facts.text: Appellant obtained Pakistan Passport No. 071377 dated April 1, 1953.

anchor.surface_text: informing him that as he had obtained Pakistan Passport No. 071377, dated April 1, 1953 he should leave India within one month from the date of service of the numberice,

facts.text: Appellant urged s.9 of Citizenship Act ultra vires and cl.3 Sch.III Citizenship Rules ultra vires.

anchor.surface_text: In support of his petition before the High Court for issue of a writ of mandamus, the appellant urged that s. 9 of the Citizenship Act, 1955 was ultra vires the Parliament and cl. 3 of Sch. III to the Citizenship Rules was also ultra vires the Central Government,

facts.text: Balakrishna Ayyar J rejected appellant's contentions.

anchor.surface_text: Balakrishna Ayyar, J., rejected these companytentions.

facts.text: Division Bench held s.9 lays down objective test, no scope for enquiry claimed by appellant.

anchor.surface_text: In the view of the High Court s. 9 lays down an objective test and when the individual had brought himself within it, the law determines the legal companysequences of the situation, independently of his intent or understanding, and therefore there was numberscope for an enquiry of the nature claimed by the appellant.

facts.text: Appeal heard on December 7, 1964, notice issued to Union of India to produce orders under S.9(2).

anchor.surface_text: When this appeal was beard on December 7, 1964, numberice was issued calling upon the Union to produce the orders and proceedings under S. 9 2  of the Citizenship Act relating to the case of the appellant.

facts.text: Union of India produced relevant proceedings and order, affidavit filed by Under Secretary Ministry of Home Affairs.

anchor.surface_text: Pursuant to the direction the relevant proceedings and order have been produced and an affidavit has been filed by the Under Secretary in the Ministry of Home Affairs.

facts.text: No opportunity afforded to appellant in inquiry under Rule 30 Citizenship Rules.

anchor.surface_text: It is number companymon ground that in the inquiry companytemplated by Rule 30 of the Citizenship Rules, numberopportunity was afforded to the appellant to prove his case that he had number obtained the passport voluntarily from the High Commissioner for Pakistan.

facts.text: Appellant claims he was compelled by police to obtain passport from High Commissioner for Pakistan.

anchor.surface_text: the High Court that he was companypelled to obtain the passport from the High Commissioner for Pakistan. Balakrishna Ayyar, J., observed that the plea of the appellant was number bona fide.

facts.text: Supreme Court allowed appeal, ordered deportation not enforced until Central Government determines status according to law.

anchor.surface_text: The appeal is allowed, and it is ordered that the order of deportation passed by the Commissioner of Police, Madras shall number be enforced until the Central Government determines the status of the appellant according to law.

Later he applied to the Central Government under S. 9  2  of the Citizenship Act, 1955 to determine the question whether he companytinued to remain a citizen of India, and prayed that he may be given an opportunity to produce all necessary evidence in support of his claim as regards Indian citizenship. Without affording him that opportunity, however, the Government of India by order, dated May 7, 1958 rejected the application of the appellant under s. 9 of the Citizenship Act.

anchor.surface_text: Article 9 provides No person shall be a citizen of India by virtue of article 5, or be deemed to be a citizen of India by virtue of article 6 or article 8, if he has voluntarily acquired the citizenship of any foreign State.

concepts.interpretation: No citizenship under Arts 5,6,8 if voluntarily acquired foreign citizenship.

holdings.text: Section 9 of the Citizenship Act, 1955 was validly enacted by Parliament.

anchor.surface_text: This Court has held on the arguments presented before the Court in lzhar Ahmad Khans case 1  that s. 9 of the Act was validly enacted by the Parliament,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Follows binding precedent in Izhar Ahmad Khan v. Union of India and subsequent cases; no grounds for re-examination.

holdings.text: Rule 3 of Schedule III to the Citizenship Rules was competently made by the Central Government.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Follows binding precedent in Izhar Ahmad Khan v. Union of India; within rule-making power under s.18.

holdings.text: Rule 30 of the Citizenship Rules contemplates a quasi-judicial inquiry requiring opportunity to the affected party to make representation and adduce evidence on voluntary nature of passport acquisition.

anchor.surface_text: Determination of the question postulates an approach as in a quasi-judicial enquiry the citizen concerned must be given due notice of the nature of the action which in the view of the authority involves termination of Indian citizenship, and reasonable opportunity

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.9(2) mandates determination by prescribed authority using rules of evidence, implying enquiry with notice and opportunity per natural justice.

holdings.text: The appellant can challenge the validity of the deportation order pursuant to Central Government order under s.9(2) on the plea that he had not voluntarily obtained the Pakistan passport.

anchor.surface_text: The question which survives for determination is whether the appellant can challenge the validity of the order of the Commissioner of Police pursuant to the order made by the Central Government under s. 9(2) of the Act on the plea that he had not voluntarily obtained a passport

holdings.reasoning_summary: No opportunity was given in inquiry under Rule 30; plea of non-voluntary acquisition requires determination by authority.

holdings.text: Central Government must afford opportunity to citizen to disprove voluntary acquisition before terminating citizenship under s.9(2).

anchor.surface_text: Provision for prescribing rules of evidence... clearly indicates that the order is not to be made on the mere satisfaction of the authority without enquiry... Determination of the question postulates an approach as in a quasi-judicial

holdings.reasoning_summary: Quasi-judicial nature requires due notice and reasonable opportunity; supported by Sch.III provisions allowing rebuttal and enquiries.

holdings.text: Obtaining foreign passport under Cl.3 Sch.III raises conclusive presumption of prior voluntary foreign citizenship acquisition, but not if proved non-voluntarily obtained (by force, fraud etc.); opportunity must be given on such plea.

anchor.surface_text: Paragraph 3 raises a conclusive presumption that a citizen of India who has obtained a passport from a foreign country on any date, has before that date voluntarily acquired citizenship of that other country. By the application of the rule in Paragraph 3 the authority must regard

holdings.reasoning_summary: Presumption applies to voluntary obtaining; plea of compulsion/fraud requires opportunity to prove non-volition, consistent with overall scheme.

holdings.text: High Court erred in holding s.9 lays down objective test with no scope for enquiry into intent/volition.

anchor.surface_text: We are unable to agree with that view. If voluntary acquisition of citizenship of another country determines Indian citizenship within the meaning of s. 9(1), and by virtue of Paragraph 3 of Sch. III of the, Citizenship Rules a conclusive presumption

holdings.reasoning_summary: Incompatible with enquiry mandated by s.9(2), Rule 30, Sch.III allowing proof of non-voluntary acquisition.

holdings.text: Determination of voluntary acquisition of foreign citizenship for termination of Indian citizenship is by Indian authority under s.9(2)/Rule 30, guided by statutory rules, not by foreign issuing authority.

anchor.surface_text: But s. 9(2) read with Rule 30 confers the power to determine whether Indian citizenship is terminated upon the specified authority, and in exercising that power the authority is guided by the statutory rules of evidence.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Statutory scheme vests power in Central Government with prescribed procedure; foreign issuance not decisive.

holdings.text: Order of deportation not enforceable until Central Government determines appellant's citizenship status according to law.

anchor.surface_text: The appeal is allowed, and it is ordered that the order of deportation passed by the Commissioner of Police, Madras shall not be enforced until the Central Government determines the status of the appellant according to law.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No proper opportunity given; requires fresh determination per quasi-judicial procedure.
